headline: Apple's chip chief reportedly 'not leaving': A closer look
summary: Amid a flurry of executive departures from Apple (AAPL), Apple's chip chief Johny Srouji reportedly said on Monday that he is "not leaving" the company "anytime soon." Creative Strategies principal analyst and CEO, Ben Bajarin, joins Market Domination host Josh Lipton to discuss the reports and how consequential these executive departures could be for Apple and investors. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

headline: Apple’s Chips Chief Says He Isn’t Leaving
summary: Apple appears to be keeping hold of a key executive amid a rash of other departures.  Apple executive Johny Srouji told staff in a memo that he has no plans to leave the company “anytime soon,” according to a copy reviewed by the Journal.  The memo he sent to Apple’s hardware technologies team appeared to be a response to a Bloomberg story over the weekend that said Srouji had told Chief Executive Tim Cook that he was considering leaving in the near future.

headline: Apple Chip Chief Tells Staff He’s Not Leaving ‘Anytime Soon’
summary: “I know you’ve been reading all kind of rumors and speculations about my future at Apple, and I feel that you need to hear from me directly,” he said in a memo to his division.  “I love my team, and I love my job at Apple, and I don’t plan on leaving anytime soon.”  Bloomberg News reported over the weekend that Srouji had discussed leaving the company, indicating that he might work for a different technology firm.

raw.headline: Apple Chip Chief Tells Staff He’s Not Leaving ‘Anytime Soon’

headline: Grid Tech Stocks Are Poised to Soar Even Further Amid AI Bubble Fears
summary: Despite sector-wide gains of some 30% this year, grid tech stocks remain an attractive target, according to Steve Tusa, managing director and senior equity analyst at JPMorgan Chase & Co. Grid tech encompasses a range of hardware makers and software developers as well as utility-scale battery installers.  Take Vertiv Holdings Co., which provides microgrid and energy storage solutions to data centers.  Other grid tech stocks have also seen large gains this year, mirroring the data center boom.

headline: Oura vs Big Tech: The ring taking on Apple, Google & OpenAI
summary: Opening Bid Unfiltered is available on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube, or wherever you get your podcasts. The battle to analyze your health data has arguably never been fiercer. The Apple (AAPL) Watch has sold tens of millions of units, all of which are collecting health data. Whoop is eyeing an IPO. Not to mention, there are an array of other major players in the wearables space, such as Samsung (005930.KS) and Garmin (GRMN). Does there need to be one winner, though, as the longevity industry continues to grow in size? Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi sits down on the Opening Bid Unfiltered podcast with Oura Health CEO Tom Hale. Oura — the maker of the popular health tracking ring — is fresh off raising $900 million from a series of investors. The proceeds are being earmarked for international expansion, and perhaps a foray into payments. Hale shares his ultimate vision for Oura Health, what he has learned about leadership three years into being CEO, and the dos and don'ts of health tracking. Listen on your favorite podcast platform or watch on our website for full episodes of Opening Bid Unfiltered. Yahoo Finance's Opening Bid Unfiltered is produced by Langston Sessoms.

Not to mention, there are an array of other major players in the wearables space, such as Samsung (005930.KS) and Garmin (GRMN). Does there need to be one winner, though, as the longevity industry continues to grow in size? headline: Research Veteran Yardeni Ends 15-Year Tech Bet With Underweight Mag 7 Call
summary: “We see more competitors coming for the juicy profit margins of the Magnificent 7,” and expect that the productivity and profit margins of the rest of the S&P 500 will be boosted by tech, said Wall Street research veteran Ed Yardeni.  The Magnificent 7 stocks were mixed in premarket trading on Monday, with Tesla Inc., Meta Platforms Inc. and Nvidia Corp. underperforming peers.  The Magnificent 7 merits special caution as “they’re competing more aggressively against each other and they’ve got more competition coming out of nowhere” Yardeni said in an interview with Bloomberg Television on Monday.

raw.headline: Research Veteran Yardeni Ends 15-Year Tech Bet With Underweight Mag 7 Call

headline: Riyadh Air and IBM Partner to Launch World's First AI-Native Airline
summary: At IBM Think Riyadh 2025, IBM (NYSE: IBM) and Riyadh Air announced a major milestone in their collaboration, unveiling Riyadh Air as the world's first AI-native airline. Designed from the ground up without legacy patch work, these AI-driven operations provide the foundation to transform guest and employee experiences and set a new benchmark for innovation in the aviation industry.
